trustfund: TF026361-PHRD-ROMANIA FOREST DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM,TF040005-ROMANIA - FORESTRY DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM,TF040762-ROMANIA FOREST DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM,TF040922-ROMANIA: FORESTRY DEVELOPMENT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Forest Development
            Project for Romania were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, Bank performance was satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: agreeing on the structure and development of new
            information management systems for the forest sector,
            programming the software, and instituting the proper use of
            those new systems can take considerable time. At appraisal,
            very few cost-effective systems existed. For future Forest
            Management Information and Monitoring System (FMIMS)
            developments, off-the-shelf systems are now available at
            reasonable costs. In recent years, the Bank has been
            hesitant to invest in forestry, and in particular, road
            activities because of heightened non-government organization
            (NGO) attention. Because of the generally good outcomes of
            this project, especially with access roads, and the strong
            environmental and social linkages, this positive experience
            could offer an important lesson for the Bank both in terms
            of how to engage NGOs in seeking a way forward, but also in
            addressing critical safeguards issues. A lesson emerging
            from the project is that small-scale forest owners may
            require initial incentives to form associations and grow,
            such as training and technical support, accessing financing
            through a revolving fund partially funded through member
            contributions, tapping new forest carbon funds, etc. It is
            important that at effectiveness, projects have made good
            progress to establish a robust monitoring and evaluation
            (M&E) system with a baseline, plus a program and format
            for regular collection of data on input/outputs, processes,
            institutional development, impacts and outcomes.
